message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests a femoral pseudoaneurysm after arterial puncture. Treatment includes ultrasound-guided thrombin injection, which is the most appropriate next best step in management. Coil embolization or surgical repair may be considered if thrombin injection is not successful. Ultrasound-guided compression is an outdated method and not commonly used.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a femoral artery pseudoaneurysm. Ultrasound-guided thrombin injection is the preferred treatment for femoral artery pseudoaneurysms, as it can be performed with local anesthesia and low risk of complications. Coil embolization and surgical repair are usually reserved for larger pseudoaneurysms or cases where thrombin injection is unsuccessful. Ultrasound-guided compression may also be used but has a higher risk of complications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are consistent with a femoral artery pseudoaneurysm, and ultrasound-guided thrombin injection is the most appropriate next step according to the American College of Radiology’s appropriateness criteria. Coil embolization may be considered as well depending on the size and location of the pseudoaneurysm, but it is not the most appropriate initial step. Ultrasound-guided compression and surgical repair are not the first-line options for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of a pseudoaneurysm, as indicated by the tender, pulsatile mass and loud bruit. Ultrasound-guided thrombin injection is a minimally invasive procedure that can be used to treat pseudoaneurysms. Coil embolization and surgical repair are other treatment options, but they are more invasive and may carry greater risks. Ultrasound-guided compression is not appropriate for this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest the presence of a femoral artery pseudoaneurysm, which is best managed with ultrasound-guided thrombin injection. Coil embolization and surgical repair are also options, but ultrasound-guided thrombin injection is less invasive and has fewer complications. Ultrasound-guided compression may be appropriate for smaller pseudoaneurysms, but a 3-cm mass is too large for this option.

Ultrasound-guided thrombin injection is a minimally invasive treatment option for this condition. Coil embolization and surgical repair are other options but may not be necessary depending on the size and severity. Ultrasound-guided compression is typically used for small pseudoaneurysms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings are consistent with a femoral artery pseudoaneurysm. The most appropriate next step in management is ultrasound-guided thrombin injection, which is a minimally invasive technique that can be done under local anesthesia to induce prompt thrombosis within the sac. Coil embolization and surgical repair are more invasive and may carry more risks. Ultrasound-guided compression may be effective for small or superficial pseudoaneurysms but is less likely to be effective in this case.

Ultrasound-guided thrombin injection is a minimally invasive procedure that can be used to treat pseudoaneurysms. Coil embolization and surgical repair are more invasive options. Ultrasound-guided compression can also be used but may be less effective in larger pseudoaneurysms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest that he has a femoral artery pseudoaneurysm. Ultrasound-guided thrombin injection is a minimally invasive and effective treatment option for pseudoaneurysms. Coil embolization and surgical repair may also be options, but thrombin injection is the preferred initial approach. Ultrasound-guided compression may be used for small pseudoaneurysms, but for a 3-cm mass, thrombin injection or surgical repair is more appropriate.
